senses.de: A topic or issue to talk, think, or deal with
senses.ex: Climate change is a serious matter that requires global attention.

Tips.title: Conversation Starter
Tips.description: Use 'matter' to introduce a topic for discussion in formal and informal contexts.
Tips.example: Let's discuss the matter of the upcoming project.

Tips.title: Expressing Concern
Tips.description: 'Matter' can indicate a problem or concern when discussed among people.
Tips.example: Is everything alright? You look like you have a matter on your mind.

senses.de: Physical substance in general, everything in the universe
senses.ex: Scientists study the properties of matter to understand its structure and behavior.

Tips.title: Scientific Use
Tips.description: In science, 'matter' refers to anything with mass and volume, used in educational settings.
Tips.example: We learned that liquids and gases are both states of matter.

Tips.title: Broad Concept
Tips.description: 'Matter' in science encompasses all physical objects, a foundational concept in physics and chemistry.
Tips.example: Matter can change states from solid to liquid or gas.

senses.ex: Your opinion is of no matter to the decision we make.

Tips.title: Indicating Importance
Tips.description: Emphasize the weight or significance of a topic by considering it 'a matter' of something.
Tips.example: It's a matter of safety, so please wear your helmets.

Tips.title: Dismissing Significance
Tips.description: Using 'no matter' can minimize the perceived importance of something.
Tips.example: It's of no matter whether we take the train or the bus.

senses.de: To be of importance or significance
senses.ex: It doesn't matter where you come from; what matters is where you are going.

Tips.title: Current Issue
Tips.description: Use 'matter' when referring to a problem currently being experienced or considered.
Tips.example: We should resolve the matter of the late shipments immediately.

Tips.title: Subject Relevance
Tips.description: The phrase 'matter at hand' helps to focus attention on the topic currently under discussion.
Tips.example: Let's focus on the matter at hand, which is budget allocation.

senses.de: A situation or subject of concern
senses.ex: There seems to be a matter of misunderstanding between us.
We need to check the matter before it goes to print.

Tips.title: Publishing Term
Tips.description: In publishing, 'matter' can be used to refer to text and illustrations for printing.
Tips.example: Please review the matter carefully for any typos before it's printed.

Tips.title: Content Preparation
Tips.description: Refers to preparing or examining content before it's made publicly available.
Tips.example: The editorial team is discussing the final print matter tomorrow.

Concern.wordDefinition:
Concern means to feel worried or anxious about something.

It is used when you care about a particular person or situation and want to make sure everything is okay. For example, "I am concerned about my friend's health.".

Concern is used when there is emotional involvement or care, while matter describes a situation or topic that needs attention.

Element.wordDefinition:
Element refers to a simple substance that cannot be broken down into smaller substances by any chemical reaction.

There are 118 known elements in the periodic table, such as hydrogen, oxygen, carbon, etc. Elements are the basic building blocks of all matter, and they have unique physical and chemical properties.

Matter can be either a pure substance or a mixture of substances. Pure substances can be elements or compounds, while mixtures are made up of two or more substances that are physically combined but not chemically bonded.

So, in simple terms, an element is a type of pure substance that cannot be broken down into simpler substances, while matter can be anything that takes up space and has mass, including elements, compounds, and mixtures.

Entity.wordDefinition:
An entity refers to something that exists, whether it is tangible or intangible.

In essence, anything that has its own existence can be considered an entity.

So, while an entity can refer to anything that exists, matter specifically refers to the physical substance that makes up the world around us.

They are both applicable in different contexts - entity can be used to refer to a business or a personal identity, while matter can be used to discuss the properties and physical makeup of the world's physical substances.

Issue.wordDefinition:
Issue generally refers to a problem or concern that needs to be resolved or addressed.

It can also be used to refer to a topic that is being discussed or debated. For example, the issue of climate change or the issue of gun control.

Both words can be used in various contexts, but issue is often associated with problems or conflicts, while matter is more about a topic or subject that is important or significant.

Material.wordDefinition:
Material typically refers to a tangible thing, such as fabric or wood, that can be used to make something else. It's often used in the context of manufacturing or construction.

To summarize: material is a specific type of matter that can be used to make something, while matter can refer to anything that takes up space and has mass.

Object.wordDefinition:
Objects refer to specific things made of matter that can be seen and touched.

For example, a football is an object made of matter, specifically plastic and air molecules. A mountain is also an object made of matter, specifically rock and dirt.

Matter is a general term for the substance that makes up everything, while objects are specific things made of matter that can be observed and interacted with.

Subject.wordDefinition:
Subject refers to the broad area of interest or study that the matter falls under. For example, in a history class, the subject might be World War II and the matter might be the causes of the war.

Matter refers to the specific thing or issue being discussed, while subject refers to the broader topic or area of study that the matter falls under.

Substance.wordDefinition:
Substance refers to a particular type of matter that has uniform and distinct properties. For example, water is a substance as it has a particular formula (H2O) and will always have the same properties such as boiling point and freezing point.

Matter refers to anything that has mass and takes up space, while substance refers to a particular type of matter with uniform properties.

Matter can be applied to anything that exists, while substance is applicable when describing specific types of matter.

Thing.wordDefinition:
Thing is a more general term referring to any object or entity, whether physical or abstract.

It can be used in everyday conversations, and it often refers to something that is less specific or more general.

You might say "I need to pick up a few things from the store," to refer to a general set of items you need to buy.

Topic.wordDefinition:
Matter refers to the substance or material of something, while the word topic refers to the subject or theme being discussed.

If you are discussing the topic of healthy eating, you are talking about the subject of healthy eating, but not necessarily the physical make-up of specific foods.

In simpler terms, matter refers to the actual substance or material of something, while topic refers to the subject or theme being discussed.

quotes.Text: Once you get on the playing field it's not about whether you're liked or not liked. All that matters is to play at a high level and do whatever it takes to help your team win. That's what it's about.
quotes.Title: American Basketball Player
quotes.Name: LeBron James

quotes.Text: The experience of life consists of the experience which the spirit has of itself in matter and as matter, in mind and as mind, in emotion, as emotion, etc.
quotes.Title: Novelist
quotes.Name: Franz Kafka

quotes.Text: Don't matter if you're rich, poor or whatever, you just want to be able to have your own experiences in life and listen and learn from other people.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Future

quotes.Text: In the big picture, it doesn't really matter if we never made a record, or we never sang a song. That isn't important.
quotes.Title: British Musician
quotes.Name: George Harrison

quotes.Text: Anyone who doesn't take truth seriously in small matters cannot be trusted in large ones either.
quotes.Title: German Physicist
quotes.Name: Albert Einstein

quotes.Text: Life is not a matter of holding good cards, but sometimes, playing a poor hand well.
quotes.Title: American Novelist
quotes.Name: Jack London

quotes.Text: Life was always a matter of waiting for the right moment to act.
quotes.Title: Brazilian Novelist
quotes.Name: Paulo Coelho

quotes.Text: I just like seeing the world, and it doesn't matter where.
quotes.Title: American Baseball Player
quotes.Name: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar

quotes.Text: No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted.
quotes.Title: Greek Author
quotes.Name: Aesop

quotes.Text: Life is a matter of really tough choices.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: Joe Biden
